FullDescription: The rise of advanced urban cultures in Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro, showing sophisticated planning.
The composition of the Vedas, establishing foundational religious  and social structures (e.g., Varna system).
Founding of Buddhism, which profoundly impacted Indian and Asian philosophy and culture.
Chandragupta Maurya unites most of the subcontinent, creating one of India's largest empires.
Emperor Ashoka's brutal conquest of Kalinga, leading to his conversion to Buddhism and reign of peace.
Period of great achievements in science, mathematics (e.g., zero concept), art, and literature (e.g., Kalidasa).
Muhammad bin Qasim's conquest, marking the  first major arrival of Islamic influence in the subcontinent.
Qutb-ud-din Aibak establishes the first major Islamic  empire centered in Delhi.
Emergence of a dominant Hindu kingdom in South India, known for its extensive temple building.
Babur defeats Ibrahim Lodhi at Panipat, beginning a powerful  empire known for its architectural splendor.
Queen Elizabeth I grants a charter, marking  the formal beginning of British involvement in trade.
The Great Revolt/Sepoy Mutiny challenges British authority, leading to the end of Company rule.
Established in Dhaka to safeguard the political rights of Muslims in British India.
India gains independence from British rule, but is partitioned into the Union of India and Pakistan.
The Indian Constitution is adopted, establishing a sovereign, socialist, secular, and democratic republic.
